Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: tuist
Description: Generate, build and test your Xcode projects. For more info please see https://docs.tuist.io/

Arguments.Name: --help
Arguments.Description: Show help for tuist

Arguments.Name: build
Arguments.Description: Build the project in the current directory

Arguments.Name: --build-output-path
Arguments.Description: Build the project to a custom directory, example usage: 'tuist build --build-output-path .build':

Arguments.Name: --device
Arguments.Description: Build the project to a specific device, example usage: 'tuist build --device "iPhone X"':

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Build the project to a specific OS, example usage: 'tuist build --os 14.0':

Arguments.Name: scheme
Arguments.Description: scheme

Arguments.Name: cache
Arguments.Description: A set of utilities related to the caching of targets. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/building-at-scale/caching USAGE: tuist cache <subcommand>

Arguments.Name: warm
Arguments.Description: Warms the local and remote cache

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the project whose targets will be cached

Arguments.Name: --profile
Arguments.Description: The name of the profile to be used when warming up the cache

Arguments.Name: --xcframeworks
Arguments.Description: When passed it caches the targets for simulator and device using xcframeworks

Arguments.Name: --dependencies-only
Arguments.Description: If passed, the command doesn't cache the targets passed in the `--targets` argument, but only their dependencies

Arguments.Name: print-hashes
Arguments.Description: Print the hashes of the cacheable frameworks in the given project

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the project whose targets will be cached

Arguments.Name: --profile
Arguments.Description: The name of the profile to be used when warming up the cache

Arguments.Name: --xcframeworks
Arguments.Description: When passed it caches the targets for simulator and device using xcframeworks

Arguments.Name: clean
Arguments.Description: Clean all the data generated by Tuist. USAGE: tuist clean [<clean-categories> ...] [--path <path>]

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the project that should be cleaned

Arguments.Name: plugins
Arguments.Description: Clean only the plugins cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean plugins':

Arguments.Name: builds
Arguments.Description: Clean only the builds artifacts cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean builds':

Arguments.Name: tests
Arguments.Description: Clean only the tests cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean tests':

Arguments.Name: generatedAutomationProjects
Arguments.Description: Clean only the automation projects cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean generatedAutomationProjects':

Arguments.Name: projectDescriptionHelpers
Arguments.Description: Clean only the project description helpers cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean projectDescriptionHelpers':

Arguments.Name: manifests
Arguments.Description: Clean only the manifests cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist clean manifests':

Arguments.Name: clean-categories
Arguments.Description: clean-categories

Arguments.Name: fetch
Arguments.Description: Dependencies can be fetched by running the following command. They are stored in your project's `Tuist/Dependencies` directory. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/dependencies

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the workspace or project whose dependencies will be fetched/updated. The default is the current directory

Arguments.Name: --update
Arguments.Description: Clean only the builds artifacts cache generated by Tuist, example usage: 'tuist fetch --update':

Arguments.Name: edit
Arguments.Description: Editing your projects is easy; position yourself in a directory where there's a project defined and run the edit command. It will open a temporary Xcode project with all the project manifests and the project description helpers, so you will be able to edit the whole project configuration. After making changes you can run the target from Xcode and it will call tuist generate for you. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/edit

Arguments.Name: --permanent
Arguments.Description: The project is deleted automatically once you are done with editing. If you wish to generate and keep the project in the current directory, you can run the command passing the --permanent argument. That will generate a Manifest.xcodeproj project that you can open manually

Arguments.Name: graph
Arguments.Description: Generates a graph from the workspace or project in the current directory. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/graph USAGE: tuist graph [--skip-test-targets] [--skip-external-dependencies] [--format <format>] [--algorithm <algorithm>] [<targets> ...] [--path <path>] [--output-path <output-path>]

Arguments.Name: --skip-test-targets
Arguments.Description: Excludes test targets from the generated graph

Arguments.Name: --skip-external-dependencies
Arguments.Description: Excludes external dependencies from the generated graph

Arguments.Name: --format
Arguments.Description: If you prefer to have the dot or json representations of the graph and render it separately. Available formats: dot, png, json (default: png)

Arguments.Name: format
Arguments.Description: format

Arguments.Name: dot
Arguments.Description: format

Arguments.Name: png
Arguments.Description: format

Arguments.Name: json
Arguments.Description: format

Arguments.Name: --algorithm
Arguments.Description: Available formats: dot, neato, twopi, circo, fdp, sfddp, patchwork (default: dot)

Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the definition of the project. Default is current directory

Arguments.Name: project dir

Arguments.Name: --output-path
Arguments.Description: The path to where the image will be exported. When not specified, it exports the image in the current directory

Arguments.Name: output path

Arguments.Name: --no-open
Arguments.Description: If set, the generated graph is not opened automatically. Default is yes

Arguments.Description: If set, show only the targets for the given platform. Default is all platforms. Available platforms: ios, macos, tvos, watchos

Arguments.Name: generate
Arguments.Description: Generates an Xcode workspace to start working on the project. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/generate

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the definition of the project. Default is current directory

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: --no-open
Arguments.Description: Don't open the project after generating it. Default is false

Arguments.Name: --xcframeworks
Arguments.Description: When passed it uses xcframeworks (simulator and device) from the cache instead of frameworks (only simulator). Default is false

Arguments.Name: --no-cache
Arguments.Description: Ignore cached targets, and use their sources instead.	Default is false

Arguments.Name: --profile
Arguments.Description: The name of the cache profile

Arguments.Name: cache profile
Arguments.Description: cache profile

Arguments.Name: sources
Arguments.Description: sources

Arguments.Name: migration
Arguments.Description: To help developers with the process of adopting Tuist, Tuist provides a set of commands under tuist migration. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/migration

Arguments.Name: settings-to-xcconfig
Arguments.Description: It's recommended to make .xcconfig files the source of truth for build settings. For that, Tuist provides a tuist migration settings-to-xcconfig command that extracts the build settings from targets and projects

Arguments.Name: --xcodeproj-path
Arguments.Description: Required. Path to the Xcode project whose build settings will be extracted

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: --xcconfig-path
Arguments.Description: Required. Path to the Xcode project whose build settings will be extracted

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: --target
Arguments.Description: Optional. The name of the target whose build settings will be extracted. When not passed, it extracts the build settings of the project

Arguments.Name: target
Arguments.Description: target

Arguments.Name: check-empty-settings
Arguments.Description: After making .xcconfig files the source of truth for build settings, it's important to ensure that build settings are no longer set to the project. To help with that, Tuist includes a command that fails if the build settings of a project or a target are not empty

Arguments.Name: --xcodeproj-path
Arguments.Description: Required. Path to the Xcode project whose build settings will be checked

Arguments.Name: --target
Arguments.Description: Optional. The name of the target whose build settings will be checked. When not passed, it checks the build settings of the project

Arguments.Name: list-targets
Arguments.Description: When passed it uses xcframeworks (simulator and device) from the cache instead of frameworks (only simulator). Default is false

Arguments.Name: --xcodeproj-path
Arguments.Description: Required. Path to the Xcode project whose build settings will be checked

Arguments.Name: scaffold
Arguments.Description: Generates new project based on a template. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/scaffold USAGE: tuist scaffold <template> [--json] [--path <path>] <subcommand>

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the folder where the template will be generated (Default: Current directory)

Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: --json
Arguments.Description: The output in JSON format

Arguments.Name: --name
Arguments.Description: The name of the generate project

Arguments.Name: --platform
Arguments.Description: The platform used by the project

Arguments.Name: platform

Arguments.Name: template
Arguments.Description: template

Arguments.Name: list
Arguments.Description: Lists available scaffold templates

Arguments.Name: test
Arguments.Description: Tests a project. For more info see https://docs.tuist.io/commands/test USAGE: tuist test [<scheme>] [--clean] [--path <path>] [--device <device>] [--os <os>] [--configuration <configuration>] [--skip-ui-tests] [--result-bundle-path <result-bundle-path>] [--retry-count <retry-count>]

Arguments.Name: --path
Arguments.Description: The path to the directory that contains the project to be tested

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: --clean
Arguments.Description: When passed, it cleans the project before testing it

Arguments.Name: --device
Arguments.Description: Test on a specific device

Arguments.Name: device
Arguments.Description: device

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Test with a specific version of the OS

Arguments.Name: os
Arguments.Description: os

Arguments.Name: --configuration
Arguments.Description: The configuration to be used when testing the scheme

Arguments.Name: --skip-ui-tests
Arguments.Description: When passed, it skips testing UI Tests targets

Arguments.Name: --result-bundle-path
Arguments.Description: Path where test result bundle will be saved

Arguments.Name: --retry-count
Arguments.Description: Tests will retry <number> of times until success. Example: if 1 is specified, the test will be retried at most once, hence it will run up to 2 times. (default: 0)

Arguments.Name: times
Arguments.Description: times
